objinfo.printdate: c. 1804-05The characteristics of the color printing indicate that this impression is the first one printed c. 1804-05. The second impression in that printing session is *God Judging Adam* in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York (Butlin 295).
objinfo.medium: color printed relief etching(?) with water color and pen and ink additions to the impressionThe printing matrix would appear to be a copperplate etched in relief. Evidence for this is provided by indentations around some of the printed areas representing God in the impression in the Philadelphia Museum of Art (Butlin 296); and letters blind-embossed lower right, probably created by a platemaker's mark, visible in the impression in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York (Butlin 295).

provenance.name: Tate Collection
provenance.note: Acquired by Thomas Butts in 1805 from Blake; Thomas Butts, Jr., apparently by inheritance in 1845; Frederick J. Butts, apparently by inheritance in 1862; his widow, c. 1905, by inheritance; sold 1906 through Carfax and Co., London, to W. Graham Robertson; given 1939 by Robertson to the Tate Gallery (now Tate Collection).

objnote.p: "God Judging Adam," loosely based on Genesis 3:17-19, embodies Blake's criticism of legalistic tyranny, judgment, and punishment of the sort he also explores through the character of Urizen in the illuminated books of the mid-1790s. God, riding on a fiery chariot, holds his book of laws on his lap and points toward Adam with his extended right arm. Adam's long beard indicates that he has already been marked by mortality.
A title, "God speaking to Adam," is inscribed in pencil below the design, almost certainly not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: God, who is old, gowned, and bearded and has long hair, sits on a flaming chariot drawn by two horses with flame-like manes and tails. He extends his right arm, hand, and index finger to point in judgment at the nude and hunched or bowing form of Adam, who stands before him with eyes down and face partly obscured by his long, flowing beard. God’s left hand rests on a book or tablet (of laws?) on his lap. God may be holding the horses' reins in his right hand, or a rod, scepter, or beam of light (?) pointing at Adam. Beams of light radiate from the flaming disc or globe behind God. Grass, moss, lichens, or some such vegetation may be growing beneath the feet of Adam and the horses.

component.illusobjdesc: God sits on a chariot of flame. He is bearded, gowned, and old, and has long hair. Flames surround him as he faces to the left with his head bent slightly forward and down to look at Adam. His expression and posture may suggest anger. His right arm, hand, and index finger are extended to point at Adam, who stands before him; God may also be using his right hand to hold the horses' reins or a lightly-colored rod or scepter. His left arm is bent at the elbow, and his left hand rests on the book or tablet on his lap. His bare left foot is visible beneath the hem of his gown, and appears to be resting on a platform of the chariot.
A book or tablet (of laws?) rests on God’s lap.

God may be holding a scepter or rod in his right hand, pointed toward Adam. Given its light coloring, this might even be a beam of light. Alternatively, this line could simply be one of the reins extending to the horses, although the reins are darkly colored elsewhere in the design and a dark line (the rein?) can be seen slightly above the lightly-colored line extending from God's hand.

God sits on a chariot that seems to be made mostly of fire. Flames rise upward behind him, sideways beneath his body, and downwards below his foot. The circle or globe behind God is filled with flames; it may be the sun. God’s foot rests on a plinth-like platform of the chariot.

Two horses, facing left, pull the chariot upon which God sits. The front-most horse strides to the left with its front left hoof and back right hoof. The legs of the horse behind it are not pictured. The horses have flame-like manes and tails and are wearing harnesses. One rein extends to the right towards God.

Adam, nude, muscular, and old, stands before God with his shoulders hunched over in a bow, his head bent forward, and his eyes down. This posture suggests reverence and perhaps fear. He has long hair, with a prominent forelock, and his beard obscures the lower part of his face. He faces to the right with his left leg bent behind him, and his left foot poised on tiptoe. He may be striding toward God. His arms (or at least his right arm) are probably bent upward, for his right hand is raised to his forehead and his palms may be together in prayer or supplication.
Beams of light or radiance extend from the disc or globe behind God’s chariot and fill the sky.
The hues and reticulations of the color printing suggest that grass, moss, lichens, or some such vegetation grow beneath the feet of Adam and the horses.
